reviewText:
Monopoly is an old classic from my childhood. I love to play it, and have owned many copies of the broad game. Additionally I‚Äôve owned several video game versions as well. My recommendation on this game is split, as I will expand upon below. With this version there are several things I'd like to comment on...

Pros...
--Interactive dice roles
--Animated piece movement
--Changeable backgrounds
--Includes two or three of the common/house rules as options
--The game allows human players to cheat
--There are several advanced features like statistics on how many times you or another player has landed on a property and probability of it happening in the next roll

Cons...
--No Multiplayer (over the internet, you can play with up to three others on the same computer)
--Limited to four players whether 3 AI and 1 Human player or 4 Human players the limit is 4 (The board game and several video game counterparts allows for 6-8 players including the predecessor of this version)
--The Hard level is not Hard enough (In fact it is a joke)
--Several common/house rules are missing as options (as shown in multiple rule books published by Parker Brothers and/or Hasbro, if you include two or three you should include all)
--The Community Chest/Chance cards are chosen completely at random every time, so it is possible to get the same card twice in a row or within two or three draws  (something that next to never happens on the board game, but it happens very often in this version)
--When you change windows off the Monopoly window the game pauses (instead of finishing the moves for the AI players)
--You always face the red side of the board and the camera jerks around constantly to follow the animation ( additionally there is no free movement to see where opponent pieces are on the board)

In general as you can see the con list is larger than the pro list, and I could make it larger still. This version of the game is basically just ok. It is a way to pass the time, especially if you like Monopoly. So from that standpoint I would recommend this game.

There is no challenge to this game though. Whether you are playing on Easy or Hard you cannot honestly tell the difference.  If you want a challenge I suggest an older version of Monopoly called Monopoly 2008 published by GameHouse and TIKGames. It was and may still be available through realArcade. If not there are still copies available through second hand game stores as it was published on CD as well. In my opinion EA/PopCap Games dropped the ball here as they had an excellent start in this older version when they purchased the rights to this game and the Monopoly brand. Monopoly 2008 still is not multiplayer but it has basically all the house rules as options, and the Hard mode is well hard. So from this standpoint I say pass on this game.

All and all there is plenty of room for improvement here. If this game gets updated to fix some of the cons listed above I will remove this review and give it another chance. Until then I just use this game to play with friends, and ignore the AI. It is the only reasonable use in my opinion of this version. The Previous (Monopoly 2008) version is what I play when I want to play the computer.

reviewText: There are few things more heartbreaking than to have played this game very well, to have established paying properties out in front of the computer players, only to be cheated round after round, hitting every costly spot on the board, while the computer opponents skip happily over your properties turn after turn.\n\nHaving played hundreds of games against the computer, it's more than obvious that the different skill levels are accomplished by rigging the dice.  At the end of each game, a table of throws shows a natural distribution, more or less, but the timing of when those throws either benefit or hurt you is controlled, without a doubt.  For the hard" level. it's set on a 1/2 - 2/3 bias; whereby you will make good throws 1/3 of the time
date: while your computer opponents have good throws 2/3 of the time.  Hundreds of games have taught me that."

reviewText:
Monopoly with fancy graphics. You are able to play against 3 opponents. They are either controlled by a ai or yourself. There¬¥s no online multiplayer. There¬¥s no option to change the language.

The boardgame revolves around trading properties.  Everything works fine except for one thing.... the ai. The ai never propose a deal in your favor. The ai consistently give eachother what they want for no cost. Games at a higher difficulty becomes a race against the clock. It¬¥is not unusual for the ai to have a hotel before you hit the start tile for the fourth time in the hardest difficulty. As soon as one ai get a few buildings up, the rest of them goes bankrupt to that ai.

The ai is so simple in this game that the game itself loses it¬¥s replayability. Each game feels the same, there's no twists or new situations. There's just one pattern for the ai to use and it shows.


The whole game feels like a moneygrab.  It¬¥s probably beacuse it lacks the two things you would want from a Pc version. A online multiplayer and a proper Ai. You have to play against real people at your Pc to make this game fun. I would rather buy a physical copy in that case.

reviewText:
While the game has a lot of flash and wow factor, what it doesn't have is much to offer in terms of gameplay.
The A.I does offer a challenge, I do find trading is one of the more polished things of the game. The A.I doesn't just set values, it does negotiates and even cuts slack from time to time.

But the game is far from polished. Unfortunately I have encountered bugs of one kind or another. one inparticular which destroyed the flow of the game is when the mouse cursor freezes while trying to roll the dice. It's endlessly frustrating to sit there at the start of my turn waiting for my mouse to unfreeze so I can take my turn. Unfortunately this bug alone is enough to stop me playing and quit to play something else.

One of the biggest problems, and this is something I see meantioned over and over, is the games lack of multiplayer options. For a board game designed originally to be played entirely by people it seems odd that it only offers limited multiplayer from the same computer. Considering right now that free to play counterparts to monopoly already offer this feature on a truely massive scale, this is something the game severely lacks.

In short if you are looking to buy this game to play with your friend, don't. You are far better off saving your money and buying the actual board game. There is no online play option and as far as game play goes this version of monopoly only really offers an A.I to play with. Really your just paying for animated pieces and some flashy screen splashes.

reviewText: If you just have an itch to play the classic game of monopoly but no one will play with you this game is for you.  There is no online multiplayer but it does have local multiplayer.  It's good for someone like me who doesn't really care about online play for a game like this.  It also lets you play the game fast pace because you can quickly skip through the computers turns and then get back to making your moves.  No more waiting for that one pesky player that just wont go, and no worried about someone online going AFK for long periods of time.  If this sounds like something you would desire from a game this is a good pick (I travel a lot for work and it is a nice game to play when I am sitting on a cramped air plane, I have even played with other passangers I meet sitting next to me).  If this game sounds like you I would also recommend picking up the game of Risk on here as well, it is a very similar setup as this game. If you just want online play then your going to be disappointed and I would recommend avoiding this game.

reviewText: This release is a sad misguided production. Although it's accurate to the boardgame and works in the sence that you can win the game, it's impossible to follow what is going on. All through the game there are board movements and amounts coming up in the screen. In-game popups block the board partially and make it difficult to find the opponent pieces on the board. The settings don't let you change the unwanted visual effects. It does however let you change the colour of the dice. (?!?)\nI find myself going back to the event log to see what happened, who rolled the dice and why a certain amount flashed across the screen. Infogrames made a better version back in 1999. This version allowed a 2D-view of the board that allowed you to keep a good overview of the positions of the pieces, which is really helpful when making tactical decisions like when to invest in a monopoly.

reviewText:
I actually really enjoyed this.  The presentation is colourful and helpful, the animation is good and you get a full set of options for trading and managing your properties.  Sure its just Monopoly, but its a respectful treatment of the board game.

Negatives?  Well, no multiplayer - but then, would you really want to play multiplayer on a PC with a board game simulator?  It's never going to be Planetside 2, is it?  The only other downside is there are only two music tracks.  They're actually quite good in a cheesy kind of way, but I'd like many more given that the games can extend out to quite a long time.

For seven quid its probably overpriced, but get it in a sale and its thoroughly recommended.

reviewText: You know its hard to NOT recommend Monopoly, which is such a great, and all time classic game.  But this computer game version of it is terrible.  There is nothing special about it at all, nothing to recommend on it.  The animations are terrible, its hard to see where your piece, and the other player's pieces are on the board, the camera does a follow on the dice as they bounce around the board when you roll that will make you nauseating sick, the music is horrifically awful, the GUI for your current assets leaves a lot to be desired....  need I go on?   Of those first 5 complaints, the only one you can fix, is the music.  The rest, you are stuck with.  The computer doesn't make intelligent trades; its a hard ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for 7 trades in a row, offering exactly what you paid for an item, so that it completes its set.  I reject each one and a few turns later, it offers $900 for mortgaged New York Ave, when it only has $920.  Also a glitch the first time I was in jail, I had my get out of Free Jail card.  Couldn't find it, cause I cant see my stuff, especially that.  Got no offer to use it.  And I was broke, so I really could have used it.  Instead had to mortgage stuff to get out.  Next time I was in jail, it immediately popped up asking if I wanted to use it.  Well I know I didn't somehow miss the giant full screen message the first time.\n\nLong story short, for $4.00,  this was a total waste of money, but thankfully not a lot of money, and I'll probably never play it again.

reviewText:
So I got all four board games made by this developer, decided to playtest each of them.

I was expecting a horrid, boring and tiresome game after reading the below reviews.  Nothing but negative, negative, negative.  even so, I was still lacking a PC port of my all time favorite game, so I bought into it anyway.  Surprisingly, I wasn't disapointed.  I wasn't scratching my head at the UI trying to figure it out, I wasn't holding my ears shut from some horrible music theme, I wasn't slamming my head into my desk at the consistant crashes, none of it.

Instead, I was quite pleased at the little game.  It's nice, easy to work, has low system requirements, doesn't seem at all buggy, and it's just the same as I've always remembered it.  You can change the background for atmospheric effects, set your own house rules, and play with up to 4 players, all AI or human.

I suppose one thing people are mad at is no online multiplayer, it's hot-seat only, witch is rather disapointing.  Of course, I never really play multiplayer online anyway, so it's not an issue for me.

Overall though, I'd say it's worth the buy if you're in need of a PC Monopoly port.  It's simple, low requirements, small, practically plug-and-play, and has enough that'll keep me coming back for a long time.  If I find any issues with it, I'll be sure to edit them in this review once I get a tad bit more time put into it.

reviewText: You know its hard to NOT recommend Monopoly, which is such a great, and all time classic game.  But this computer game version of it is terrible.  There is nothing special about it at all, nothing to recommend on it.  The animations are terrible, its hard to see where your piece, and the other player's pieces are on the board, the camera does a follow on the dice as they bounce around the board when you roll that will make you nauseating sick, the music is horrifically awful, the GUI for your current assets leaves a lot to be desired....  need I go on?   Of those first 5 complaints, the only one you can fix, is the music.  The rest, you are stuck with.  The computer doesn't make intelligent trades; its a hard ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for 7 trades in a row, offering exactly what you paid for an item, so that it completes its set.  I reject each one and a few turns later, it offers $900 for mortgaged New York Ave, when it only has $920.  Also a glitch the first time I was in jail, I had my get out of Free Jail card.  Couldn't find it, cause I cant see my stuff, especially that.  Got no offer to use it.  And I was broke, so I really could have used it.  Instead had to mortgage stuff to get out.  Next time I was in jail, it immediately popped up asking if I wanted to use it.  Well I know I didn't somehow miss the giant full screen message the first time.\n\nLong story short, for $4.00,  this was a total waste of money, but thankfully not a lot of money, and I'll probably never play it again.

reviewText:
This is the second Hasbro game on sale this week that blows.

I've not played on anything else other than difficulty level hard, and from what I can tell, the game becomes harder only in that the other AIs cooperate in trading.  I just had two AI trade Connecticut Ave (giving the other the monopoly) for States Ave (no opportunity to build) one-for-one.  Nothing to sweeten the deal, just an even trade.

Had the same thing happen in a previous game when AI traded Boardwalk for Marvin Gardens + $2.  Gave both the chance to build.  WTF?

With the cards, AI-drawn cards generally earn them money or properties, while player-drawn cards seem to cost money every time.

Best advice is to get a minimum of one of each color early.  When someone owns ONE of a color you don't, trade for money and keep it. if they get two, they'll never give you one for anything other than a rediculous amount of cash, or  something on which they can build. Otherwise the AI will trade-f#ck you.

The only thing religious on Christmas in my family is our love of Monopoly with NO house rules, and the crap I'm seeing with the AI here is so absurd, even the worst players in real life wouldn't do.  I'm no sore loser, but it takes the fun out of it completely.

reviewText:
I love Monopoly. Despite the game's flaws, it is genuinely one of my favorite board games. Unfortunately, this particular version of it is rather poor.  It maxes out at the weird resolution of 1680 x 1050. What kind of resolution is that? Do they even sell monitors in that size? Why would a game released in 2012 not allow you to have regular 1080p? Also, the sound effects cut out after a single turn, leaving you with just the music. Also, you can only have four players, while the board game, and numerous other computer editions allow for six. The presentation is bare-bones and the environments are mostly pretty ugly.

If you want a truly great version of Monopoly for PC, go on Ebay or Amazon and track down the version from 2000 by Hasbro Interactive. That game has:
* Support for 6 players
* Fun Voice-overs
* Cool animations
* Good looking art style, despite the game's age
* Custom Board Designer
* A catchy theme song
* Feels more alive in general

A new company recently appeared and seems to be doing new versions of Hasbro board games that had previous versions on Steam. Hopefully they'll reach Monopoly, because the PC deserves a good, Modern Monopoly game.

reviewText:
Classic Monopoly with cute graphics. I admit it's lazy on my part but I prefer the compter version because my friends and I tend to simplify the math by rounding and it gets a little crazy after a while. This has the added benefit of allowing you to have AI players along with your friends so you can gang up on the AI and work together rather than against each other.

The dice mechanics are neat as well as the roll for me" option. I also love that you can allow cheating in the game. (You can choose 1 dice roll and pay half of rent once in the game if you allow cheating.)

Overall a great game for solo play or with friends."

reviewText: This game is excellent! I don't know why the reviews are mixed. There are no glitches or bugs. Every camera move is smooth (I don't know why somone said it wasn't).\n\nI give it a 10/10.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game is simply fantastic and entertaining, I really like this game but I do not recommend this game bacause it is too ease (very ease) to win with computer playing on hard mode. I always play against 3 computers (hard mode) and always win. I simply buy out missing cities paying to computer who owns such card - 2 times or 3 times more for its normal value and in this way I am able to build hotels in time and in order to prevent computer making deals I simply buy out 1 city from places where computer could make a deal with another one. In this way after some time computer is not able to bild hotels while I start to build my own ones.

So this game even in hard mode is ease to win. I thought in hard mode buying out cards from computer would not be so ease - but it is, that is why there is no point to play this game if you know you gonna win.

I hope this trading issue will be solved in future.
